[h1] Good game in theory, bad game in practice [/h1]

Gameplay wise, it's similar to Dead By Daylight but without a real person controlling the killer. You collect items, try not to die using them, help others who have died trying and finally defeat the killer (demon, in this case) by completing your tasks. The fact that the demon is controlled by the CPU allows for the killer to get better, as the players progress, making each step more frightening than the last. So far so good.

[b] Here is the big catch though [/b]

You can play with up to 4 people at once and if you do exactly that, the game will likely be fun. However, if you dare to not have 3 friends who all happen to be free at the same time as you, the game becomes [b] heavily unbalanced. [/b] You need to make 10 sacrifices in a round to win and at around sacrifice 7, the demon begins acting like it's on super fentanyl and winning becomes practically impossible. You need to use all of your luck for the entire year at once just for a win:

- The demon becomes way too fast. Even when you have the speed perc enabled, it will eventually be faster than you. Combine that with the next thing, and you're doomed:

- Red eyes of invincibility. The demon becomes invincible right after you stun it the first time. All you can do at this point is run away. Due to how fast the demon recovers, though, the demon will likely not only catch up to you, it will do so with such accuracy, you'll think Mossad themselves gave him your coordinates. This is also an issue:

- The demon sometimes knows where you are, even when it's not supposed to. Just now, a friend of mine, who has hiding behind a solid object in a room the demon usually doesn't just stumble into the entire time, got killed by exactly that. Either Mossad gave him his coordinates, or the demon spontaneously mutated to be able to smell where players are but, without seeing either of us running into the room, he burst in, walked up to our hiding spot like a guided missile, and slimed my friend in front of me.

The "best way" to win a round without having 3 other people playing with you at once is by collecting all of the items prior to the demon being mad at you (at the beginning, when no progress has been made yet, the demon walks around without hunting you. still might kill you, though), stacking them at the altar and then just using all of the items in bulk, where possible, minimizing the time you have to spend looking for items while the demon is active and therefore lowering your chance of impending doom. Be honest, [i] does this sound fun to you? [/i] To me, that sounds like a collecting items simulator. No fun there.

So yeah, the developers definitely have some work to do. Fix the AI of the demon and make the game more balanced, based on the player count. Once they fix that, awesome game that is fun to play. Currently, collecting items and dying without it being your fault simulator.

Beware, buyer, of the Redditors in the comment section here glazing the game. There is definitely an imbalance and everyone who says otherwise is underhating.

Maybe it's balanced for 4 player rounds, but like 2-player rounds are not fun as all after 6/7 sacrifices..

On "Normal", which should be the middle (but atm it feels like "hard"), there are way too many mobs spawning, which costs too much UV flashlight, so you often can't save yourself.
Also, the possessed person of the map is too "aggressive" on normal mode.
Like, after 2-3 sacrifices they already need to be flashed 2-3 times.. so its basically just running away, waiting for the red eyes to fade away, flashing them again and hoping to not run into several minions, which is nearly impossible after 6/7+ sacrifices.

The game needs to be tuned down in those terms to be fun for solo or duo play.

I really like the idea of the game, and that the gameplay is slightly different per map, but atm I can't recommend the game for solo players or if you plan on playing with one friend.
Not everyone plans on playing always with 2-3 other friends, so I hope the game will be more balanced for solo and duo rounds at some point and maybe the gameplay will be more unique too, so not every round/try feels the same, as it does at the current state of the game. Even if the description states "not every round feels the same" .. it pretty much does. If you don't switch between the maps, the only difference is - that the items/offering points are at slightly other spawnpoints, depending on the map. Which doesn't really change how the gameplay feels.

The game still has a lot of potential, if some stuff gets changed/added and if it would be more balanced.
Will change the review, if the game gets more diversity in gameplay and more casual-friendly in terms of the difficulty.

(Some last note in terms of difficulty and balancing, it also could be a great option and solution if the game would get some kind of difficulty sliders, so we as the players can change "every" aspect (which would influence how much XP we get too) to our liking. The premise is intriguing: a group of players trying to stop a demonic cult while being hunted by a possessed entity, but the supposed horror quickly fades once you realize most of the game revolves around completing objectives and managing resources efficiently.

For the majority of the time, youâ€™re not scared: youâ€™re busy collecting items, burning or purifying objects, and coordinating with teammates. The gameplay focuses heavily on timing, organization, and communication rather than actual fear or atmosphere. Jump scares do happen, but they quickly lose impact once you understand that everything follows a predictable pattern.

After a few rounds, the gameâ€™s formula becomes painfully repetitive. The entity stops being terrifying and instead turns into an annoying obstacle disrupting your checklist. Devour might offer brief moments of tension or adrenaline, but itâ€™s far from what youâ€™d expect from a true horror experience. In the end, itâ€™s a game that demands tryharding more than courage, and once the illusion of fear fades, what remains is a repetitive, mechanical loop with little to no genuine terror.

Devour Game Review
(Disclaimer - This is just my opinion and may be unpopular or disliked. Also, game has elements of death, religion and cults so if you are sensitive to this it may not be a game for you.)

(General)
1. This is a co-op horror game, where you can play with up to 4 players including yourself.
2. The characters, locations, adds, and gameplay has different types of horror elements making it eerie and tense.

(Positive)
1. The playable cultist characters have diversity giving a decent amount of playable choices both male and female.
2. Not all cosmetic items have to be bought some can be collected throughout the maps by getting all of a certain collectable.
3. All the main antogonists per map have are unique and the concept art for them are done well. 
4. I enjoy that they tied this game to The Watchers through the first locations Antagonist as-well-as the content they chose to expand links to The Watchers.
5. Not to fan girl, but the Cowboy antagonist on the one map is really cool and his concept ,even though it is difficult as he has range, was just so cool that it was hard to get frustrated when being dropped.
6. The adds, also, had diversity and work put into them, which made them interesting.
7. The games non-playable characters and atmospehere really adde to the horror feel.
6. The game connects well with other players and doesn't drop connection while hosting, or being on the hosted server.

(Negative)
1. The game does become repetive and tedious even when playing co-op.
2. The game becomes tense rather than scary as the Antagonists can get frustarting, or you can get overpowered by adds and dropped due to the UV running out and not recharging fast enough  even with the perk.
3. For them being cultists, the storyline of it going bad because they are being themselves and performing kinda doesn't make sense as that is what they are suppose to be doing, etc.
4. The achievements were unrealisticall lengthy, which I am sure even the devs noticed with the one achievements wordplay being "This is Starting to Getting Boaring".
5. The satanic elements are overplayed and overused to hammer on cultism, but I am not sure there is any knowledge from the creator on cultism other than word of mouth making the whole premis fall flat as that being the horror element.
6. All in all I think if the game was just thought about a bit more and not just cool characters and horror elements it has potential. It being repetitive and semi-nonsensical just kinda makes it fall flat. (I am not saying I want an authentic cultist experience, but it would be cool not to just smack rituals, the number 666 and confuse Azazel with Baphomet, smooth out that you know what you are talking about, and add some eerie vibes from that perspective.)

[h1] Good game in theory, bad game in practice [/h1]

Gameplay wise, it's similar to Dead By Daylight but without a real person controlling the killer. You collect items, try not to die using them, help others who have died trying and finally defeat the killer (demon, in this case) by completing your tasks. The fact that the demon is controlled by the CPU allows for the killer to get better, as the players progress, making each step more frightening than the last. So far so good.

[b] Here is the big catch though [/b]

You can play with up to 4 people at once and if you do exactly that, the game will likely be fun. However, if you dare to not have 3 friends who all happen to be free at the same time as you, the game becomes [b] heavily unbalanced. [/b] You need to make 10 sacrifices in a round to win and at around sacrifice 7, the demon begins acting like it's on super fentanyl and winning becomes practically impossible. You need to use all of your luck for the entire year at once just for a win:

- The demon becomes way too fast. Even when you have the speed perc enabled, it will eventually be faster than you. Combine that with the next thing, and you're doomed:

- Red eyes of invincibility. The demon becomes invincible right after you stun it the first time. All you can do at this point is run away. Due to how fast the demon recovers, though, the demon will likely not only catch up to you, it will do so with such accuracy, you'll think Mossad themselves gave him your coordinates. This is also an issue:

- The demon sometimes knows where you are, even when it's not supposed to. Just now, a friend of mine, who has hiding behind a solid object in a room the demon usually doesn't just stumble into the entire time, got killed by exactly that. Either Mossad gave him his coordinates, or the demon spontaneously mutated to be able to smell where players are but, without seeing either of us running into the room, he burst in, walked up to our hiding spot like a guided missile, and slimed my friend in front of me.

The "best way" to win a round without having 3 other people playing with you at once is by collecting all of the items prior to the demon being mad at you (at the beginning, when no progress has been made yet, the demon walks around without hunting you. still might kill you, though), stacking them at the altar and then just using all of the items in bulk, where possible, minimizing the time you have to spend looking for items while the demon is active and therefore lowering your chance of impending doom. Be honest, [i] does this sound fun to you? [/i] To me, that sounds like a collecting items simulator. No fun there.

So yeah, the developers definitely have some work to do. Fix the AI of the demon and make the game more balanced, based on the player count. Once they fix that, awesome game that is fun to play. Currently, collecting items and dying without it being your fault simulator.

Beware, buyer, of the Redditors in the comment section here glazing the game. There is definitely an imbalance and everyone who says otherwise is underhating.
